title: Do you ever lose your passion for writing? - Quora

response.answer_text: From July of 2015 to September of 2016, I wrote a 300 page book (first draft was 106,000 words) and published 60 articles (so roughly 60,000 words.) I loved it. I loved the process of sitting down at a computer, with coffee in hand, writing those first words, and seeing those words progress into an article. I still love writing. I am passionate about writing. However, I’ve stopped writing as much, and have the same fear you do. Rationally, I can explain this with justifications I’ve created. There’s only so much time in the day. I have a job that requires me to do other tasks. To be completely honest, as I’m writing this, I’ve realized my own potential block that has prevented me from writing. It almost sounds funny, coming from the guy who wrote almost 200,000 words in a year. With topics ranging from my own life experiences, human behavior, psychology, book reviews, and travel, the ideas seemed to pour out of me. I think the fear is this: who will care what I write about and what if my writing is a waste of time because it won’t progress my career and brand? As I write these words, this fear sounds ridiculous. However, it’s true. My book, which is endorsed by 2 NYT best-selling authors and has gotten decent press, has only sold about 1,500 copies in the first year. My email list, which I honestly never seriously took time to grow, is only at about 150 people, despite the 60+ articles I wrote. So, at some point, I know my thought process went something like this: What’s the point? What’s the point if not many people read my work? What’s the point if my writing isn't progressing my career and brand? Whats the point in spending so much time and effort writing goddamn words on a computer? Here’s the fucking point: I enjoy it. I write for myself, because writing allows me to understand my life. I write because I love the way I feel after I overcome writer’s block, and express my ideas through words. I write because, even if it’s just one person, it feels great to share my thoughts with the world, and see how people take it. I write for me…because I enjoy it. As I’m answering your question, I’ve just gone through internal therapy to figure out why I’ve stopped writing (lol.) This is precisely the reason why I write. What I love writing about most is my own life - how my experiences, coupled with the books I read and the lessons I learn, allow me to reflect, and make progressive changes to improve my life. This is what I personally love to write about. I have no idea what you love to write about. I know it’s there, because you wouldn’t have asked this question unless you love writing. Here’s my advice, as Ive discovered in the last 5 minutes writing this: Just start writing. Sit down, with a cup o’ joe, and start answering questions on Quora that call out to you. See where it leads. That’s what I’ve just done, and I feel fucking great! Thanks for asking your question. It helped me tremendously. I hope, through dragging you through the internal battle of my own mind, you are able to take something away. Here’s to writing, because at the end of the day, it’s for us - the writers - first and foremost. The pleasure it brings. Everything else is a cherry on top.

I did, actually. When I first started writing it's because i needed to. There was so much in my head that I have never put to paper. I was bursting at the seams trying to arrange my thoughts properly in my head. It seems odd that I didn't start sooner. Now, when I started writing it was just to release whatever thoughts had been building up. When I was through with that…. Nothing. Nothing new came into my head. I was happier and more focused, now that my head was clear. But I was done. I had tried to keep going because I didn't want to feel like a quitter but I didn't want to go anymore. Not because I was scared of the outcome or insecure about my talent. I wrote for about a year. Not continuously, obviously. But there was always a couple days a week where I was typing on my tablet. It's not that I didn't enjoy writing. I just don't have a passion or need for it anymore. I'm sure once I get my head full again I'll write again.

I like to write, I'm not an official writer, just a starter, just begun writing, I have had various other activities like job, studies and other commitments lately but I've never lost my passion for writing, since I started and upto this moment I've never lost the passion, I've been exhausted, tired and sometimes situations caused me to indirectly force me take breaks from writing, but inside my mind was very much focused and available for writing if there was something to write, I just don't do it actively and daily, but I've made plans to overcome that, I used to be secretive about writing but slowly I've started to open up, Yes! I've felt hopeless but I realised that I write for myself first, I am always happy if I like my own words, everything else is just secondary. If I could write one thing that I feel I'm more passionate about is, writing. Cheers!!! All the best.

Yes, but it always returns. My personal experience is when something really stressful happens in life it can consume my attention and make it extremely difficult to even think about writing. Maslowe’s hierarchy of needs is true for me in this case-writing falls into the top tip of the triangle: self actualization. If I’m worried about my job, safety for myself or loved ones, writing is far from my mind. Fortunately, stressful events in life usually get resolved and my passion for wrting returns with a vengeance. I’d like to say it just goes dormant, hibernating until the storm has passed. But I’d also like to say I wish I continued to write during those moments. The book “How to be a Famous Writer Before You’re Dead” by Ariel Gore talks around this. Writing is the all important need and bills and household chores are secondary. I wish I had that kind of dedication and focus and mental strength. I hope you keep writing. Even if writing is not your topmost passion, the act of writing contributes to intelligence and thoughtfulness.

Yes …I do sometimes, it really happen but I go by my heart of course that's where the passion is when it comes down to writing. Certain situations can cause a blockage to the billions of ideas in your heart to write But when this happened I just find a way to get by myself with no one around no music no TV no phone and just sit and think and listen to my heart with my pen and my piece of paper to write down any word that comes from my heart It don't come over night but eventually it comes . ,

This is a tough one! I can emphatically state that i am always passionate about writing. However this perpetual passion is often stymied by a listlessness to put pen to paper. Although it may sound illogical, I do not attribute this lackadaisical bout of inactivity to either an absence or a loss of passion. I dare not term this a ‘writer’s block’ since considering my credibility (or the lack of it) in generating outputs, I am hardly qualified to attach the term ‘writer’ to myself! But yes to cut this long winded, dry and drab monologue short, I do go through phases of confounded confusion aided and abetted by an inveterate laziness that precludes me from engaging in meaningful spells of writing.

Not so much lose my passion for writing, but, life gets in the way. I am working full time and when I get home from work I have things I need to do around the house that dont give me much time anymore to sit down and get into writer mode. Its easy to get out of the habit of writing everyday. YOu have to set aside time daily for writing. Get up a few hours earlier than you normally do and get some writing done or do your "chores" then so when you get home from work, your evening is free.

I had a passion for creating stories. I usually have a lot of stories made up and ready to be written but for some reason, which i believe is lacking of practice, i cannot put them into words. I got them in my head in full details like how the wind blows or what kind of color does the leaf made when it was bathing in sunshine. But i cannot make them into something interesting to read. I write usually. But it always end up not readable or not indulging to read.

It happens when we develop interest in other lines. When we see we can shine and realize more latented in other lines. Mostly we write for others. When thee is followers we are motivated to write . When the followers drops, our interest to write also drops. This another reason for losing the passion to write. But writing skill retained as an exercise to the mind in a limited way. Some writers their priorities in life also decides the change.
No, I love to write and I always will.
